Here's a story from my abandoned book project that still deserves to be told.

Lets talk about Charlotte Davies, a.k.a "Miss Innocence": 

artist model, film actor, Vaudeville performer, and subject of a national scandal in 1915.

a 🧵

#c20th 🗃️ #vaudeville #film
1/12

I wrote this based on newspapers and photos in the LOC, and an unpublished memoir from Charlotte's daughter, Jewell, provided to me by her family.

Charlotte led an amazing life. It's been a privilege to do this research.
12/12

I've been researching Charlotte for a while now and I think that, on balance, she was a badass.

Life didn't turn out how she wanted, but she made her own path against the expectations of the time, and her patrician upbringing.

Her daughter loved her and was proud of her.
11/12

Charlotte traded on her Innocence fame for the rest of her life. She did shows, and movies (I couldn't find which ones), eventually moving to Florida, performing and running some sort of art/gift business.

Her daughter eventually married and had a family
10/12

If you'll allows me a bit of historical judgement, Briggs was a huge d-bag.

His people figured out that Charlotte's marriage to Porter was never legally finalized, a technicality which nullified her marriage to Briggs.

Charlotte got bupkis in the divorce.
9/12

Briggs' reaction was dumb becasue:

1. She'd been an artist model for a long time.
2. He was only mad when the picture was successful and naked pictures of his wife were in every shop window.

This was all during a broader moral panic over art and censorship in the US.
8/12

Here's an artists rendition of Briggs freaking out over the painting wearing Mickey Mouse gloves.

He was big in the publishing world, which meant he could talk a lot of smack about his ex in the papers.

Charlotte got roasted in the press all over the country.


7/12

In 1914, Charlotte posed for a nude painting titled "Innocence", which did really well commercially and even hung in the White House for a while. 

I've never found an image of the actual painting, but best i can tell, this is the pose.

Her husband Briggs was ... not happy.
6/12

In 1912 she married Victor Harvey Briggs, a publishing tycoon.

It was a rocky relationship that couldn't survive Charlotte's big break...

Here's a NYC phone directory showing her address in 1915.
5/12

In New York, Charlotte found work as an artist model, then in Vaudeville.

She juggled caring for her daughter and her career through a series of boarding schools both in New York and Cleveland, a single mother managing a hectic life.

Here she is playing at Hammerstien's
4/12

Charlotte and her daughter returned to Cleveland, struggling to make ends meet when a friend, a well connected theatre owner, suggested she go to New York as a performer, and made introductions for her. 

She was off to the Big Time.
3/12

Charlotte was a young society girl in Cleveland, OH. She was beautiful and artsy, marrying a man from Buffalo, NY named Harold Porter at age 18. They had a daughter together.

That marriage didn't last long, broken up by his family, but will be important later.
2/12

End 🍨🧵 12/12

It seems ridiculous, but this was the public anxiety around how Americans' romantic life was changing, and the newfound freedom that young people, particularly young women, were starting to enjoy. Freedom that continued into the 20th century, to the present. 11/12
Like this nationally syndicated story from 1880, where a young man is driven broke and insane by a hoard of zombie-like women shuffling towards the ice cream saloon. 10/12

Were women so gullible to go out with anyone who would buy them a frozen treat? Or were they bilking poor young men out of their hard earned money with their insatiable, almost feral, lust for ice cream? Who had the power? 9/12
The pundits started to wonder if this new ice-cream based dating scene was exploitative somehow, and just who was exploiting who. 8/12
Towards the end of the nineteenth century, people started actually... dating at ice cream saloons, and it caused a lot of hand wringing in the national press. 7/12

That helped change the game in terms of making romantic connections. Victorian courtship rules were rigid, and tightly controlled by a woman's family. But at the ice cream saloon you could meet who you wanted in a public space, even someone your parents didn't approve of. 6/12
But there was something else about ice cream saloons that was different: they were spaces controlled by women, where they could go when they wanted and meet who they wanted. 5/12

That's where ice cream comes in. Places called Ice Cream Saloons began to pop up throughout the country where women could get a bite to eat, serving what were thought to be "feminine" foods: sweet treats and light lunches. 4/12

Restaurants at the time weren't what we expect today. They were mainly places that served traveling men, and there were a whole bunch of unsavory things that went on there. Generally not a safe space for women. 3/12
So it's after the American Civil War, cities were getting bigger and people, namely women, couldn't visit town and return home in a few hours. They would need to eat in town. But where and what? 2/12

Stuff was often weird for Victorian women.

Lets talk about the time ice cream helped create modern dating... 🧵

All these shenanigans and put downs through the nations newspapers were important. Before radio and TV, circuses and other itinerant entertainers were the beginnings of mass American media culture, and were the huge entertainment industries of their day. 9/9

The smack talk between circuses got serious, with circuses putting down their competitors right in their ads. 

Zero punches were pulled.

Here is Barnum comparing train sizes in a way that I'm sure Freud would have had something to say about... 8/9
Or this assurance that the circus was a "Purely Legitimate Enterprise" placed right next to an image of a fanged rhinoceros that didn't exist. 7/9
Like this circus boasting about their "Special U.S. Detective Force" that was probably just a formalized goon squad. 6/9

Ads also had the strange job of assuring the public that circuses were safe, family friendly places...

... and did that by boasting about their enforcers that were able to keep away the throngs of hucksters, con men, and drunks that followed them. 5/9

Shotgun-armed bears anyone?

The US does have a right to bear arms... 4/9

Sometimes these included sensational illustrations that were certainly not part of the act. 

I'm pretty sure this circus didn't have its mandrill fight a man to death every show... 3/9

Circuses were only in town for a short time, so they had to go big with their marketing, taking out lavishly illustrated, full page adds in newspapers that promised a dizzying array of attractions and acts.

No one could miss that the circus was in town. 2/9

Lies, smack talking, and shotgun toting bears:

Lets talk about the bizarre world of circus advertising in 19th-century American newspapers.
